doc.title: European Metals & Mining
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/European Metals Mining Raising long-term gold to US2500oz. Lift price objectives for gold silver namesEuropean Metals Mi_2025-08-29

passages.text: Price Objective Change

We raise our long- term (LT) gold price \(+25\%\) to US\)2500 (real). We raise our long- term silver price \(+30\%\) to US\)35/oz (real). In our view, the conditions that have led to recent strength in gold price look likely to persist namely: (1) US structural deficit; (2) inflationary pressure from deglobalization; (3) perceived threats to independence of US central bank; and (4) global geopolitical tensions & uncertainty. Our average gold price for next six years increases \(+6\%\) to US\)3049/oz (real). Our average silver price increases \(+7.5\%\) to US\)38/oz. Our near- term gold forecasts remain unchanged: 2025E \(3356/oz, 2026E\) 3659/oz. We are bullish gold with a short-/medium- term target of US\)4000/oz.

For Gold & Silver companies, in particular, long- term prices matter because they are important drivers of a DCF valuation. Precious metal companies often (but not always) tend to own assets with shorter mine lives, so the market (and companies) tends to prefer a DCF rather than an earnings multiple as a starting point. We think that mining companies also use some assumption of long- term prices when considering capital allocation, both organic and inorganic, as well as when estimating reserves and resources. The price used by mining companies to estimate reserves is often a trailing average of c. three years. At year- end 2024, this trailing 3- year average was c. \(\) 2050/oz\$ . By year- end 2025, this could have increased to c. \(\) 2500/oz\$ .

For precious metal stocks, we typically set a price objective based on a multiple of NPV (DCF). Why? Companies with a track record of finding gold and growing reserves tend to be rewarded with premium multiples. Higher gold (and silver) prices = higher DCF. Accordingly, we raise price objectives. Higher cost producers (e.g., HAR) have more operational gearing and thus see larger increases.
Endeavour (Buy): Price objective \(+19\%\) to GBP3100 from GBP2600, 1.0x NPV. Fresnillo (Neutral): Price objective \(+18\%\) to GBP1770 from GBP1500, 2.5x NPV vs. 2.6x.

Hochschild (Buy): Price objective \(+17\%\) to GBP350 from GBP300, 0.9x NPV vs, 1.0x. Gold Fields (Buy): Price objective \(+17\%\) to GBP640 from GBP547, 1.35x NPV vs, 1.4x. Harmony (Neutral): Price objective \(+4\%\) to ZAR260 from ZAR250, 1x NPV vs. c. 1.4x.

Gold is not a "normal" commodity, in our view, hence typical supply- demand considerations & economics of supply may not matter as much, at least in the short term. That said, we consider, at the margin, ongoing impact on supply driven by declining gold grades. With the recent material increase in gold prices, we think some companies with declining reserves may choose to "fix" their reserve "balance sheets" by lowering cut- off grades. This would mean structurally higher costs and ultimately an increased proportion of higher cost supply in the cost curve. Similarly taxes related to revenues and profit cause supply curve to steepen during periods of rising prices.

We are bullish on gold, and Endeavour shares give leverage to moves in the gold price. The company is delivering volume growth by bringing new projects online. Even while investing to deliver a strong growth profile, EDV is also delivering strong capital returns with \(\) 277\(mn returned in 2024 and minimum capital returns in 2025E of\) \ \(294\) mn with upside from buybacks. We think strong anticipated FCF could underwrite material buybacks. We estimate 2026E FCF yield of \(>20\%\)

As we update our long- term gold and silver price view, we move our PO to GBp1770 (from GBp 1500) now based on c. 2.5x P/NPV (was 2.6x). We think a higher multiple is warranted during a period of rising precious metal prices (silver, gold), i.e., investors will pay a premium for "pure play" exposure to silver (FRES revenue c. \(50\%\) silver/ \(50\%\) gold).
We derive our price objective based on c.2.5x NPV 2026E

FRES is a "go- to" silver (& gold) exposed equity in London for many global investors, and although we see higher FCF generation in FY25E, we expect this growth to fade in FY26- 27E on lower production, higher costs and lower assumed metal prices. We think higher silver and gold prices will continue to support FRES shares but we are wary of the company's mixed operational track record; hence we reiterate our Neutral rating.
FRES trades on c.2.5x P/NPV, slightly above its historical average 1.9x. FRES trades on 7.2x EV/EBITDA, below its historical average of c. 8.6x.

We reiterate our Buy on Hochschild based on: (1) leverage to gold and silver. We are bullish gold calling it to \(\) 4000/oz(+20\%)\$ and silver \(\) 45/oz(+22\%)\$ in 2026E; (2) production growth from Brazilian projects; (3) high exploration potential; and (4) improved cash flow = dividend restart.
On P/NPV, HOC's shares currently trade at c.0.7x P/NPV, below its historical level. On EV/EBITDA (2026E), HOC is trading at c.2.9x, well below its historical long- term average of c. 3.7x.

We like HAR's gold price leverage and low- cost tailings retreatment growth options. The business has turned around in recent years, life extension projects push out production declines, and high gold prices could deliver US\(2- 3bn of balance sheet capacity in the next 2- 3 years. That said, we are cautious on reinvestment returns, greenfield execution risk and low asset quality. We also have ongoing concerns about HAR's safety record.

Our GBp3,100 (C\\$55) PO is based on the stock trading at 1x our estimated net present value (NPV). In the last ten years, larger cap global precious metal stocks have traded between 1.0x and 2.0x NAV.

While the gold price is a key driver of our rating, it is also a risk to our EDV valuation/forecasts. Other downside risks to our EDV valuation are 1) political/jurisdictional risk, 2) mine plan estimates in excess of EDV reserves, 3) lack of commodity diversification, 4) mine plans that are based on outstanding permits or approvals, 5) unfavourable changes in currencies, 6) unforeseen increases in input costs (i.e. oil and labour), and 7) the possibility it could lose its social license to operate at any of its mines or projects.

Upside risks are a higher- than- forecast gold price, the possibility for EDV to be acquired, unexpected exploration success and improving gold miner sentiment, leading to greater- than- expected multiple expansion.

We set our price objective (PO) of GBp1770 at c.2.5x our 2026E net present value (NPV). Higher multiples tend to be paid during periods of rising precious metal prices. We think investors would pay a premium to get "pure play" exposure to silver (FREs about \(50\%\) silver/50% gold by revenue). We use a \(5\%\) real weighted- average cost of capital (WACC) and no terminal value. Through FREs trades on average P/NPV of 1.9x with a \(- / + 1\) standard deviation range of 1.3- 2.5x.

Downside risks: Share price could decline below our price objective if the global demand for commodities slows, leading to lower metal prices, or if speculative investors exit the commodity market, leading to lower metal prices. The group also faces operational risk at its existing mines and execution risk on its growth projects. The group also faces currency risk by virtue of incurring costs in Mexican pesos but selling in US\\$. If the peso were to strengthen vs. the US\\$, the group's profitability would be negatively impacted, which might lead to negative share price performance. However, if silver and gold prices continue to rally, shares could continue to rise and present upside risks to our price objective.
Upside risks: Metal prices surprise positively. The company delivers a better and/or faster operational turnaround than we model.

Our price objective is ZAR640 (US\\$35 per ADR) and is set at 1.3x NPV. We use a sum- of- the- parts (SOTP) DCF and a \(5\%\) p.a. real discount rate over life- of- mine (LoM) cash flows. We estimate that GFI's NPV multiple has ranged between 0.7x and 1.3x (1x standard deviation) over the past c.12 years. We use a 1.4x multiple, above the historical average for Gold Fields as a higher multiple is paid during times of rising gold prices.

The upside risks to our PO: Successful delivery of Salares Norte project, Continuous momentum at South Deep turning this previously problematic operation into a sustainably cash flow generative mine, Resource and reserve conversions extending life of mines in excess of our assumptions, Higher- than- expected gold price, Weaker- than- expected producer currencies, including the ZAR and AUD, Lower- than- expected cost inflation.
The downside risks to our PO:

Execution risk on projects, in particular the greenfield Windfall project, Environmental restrictions on mining at Salares Norte owing to difficulties with chinchilla relocation, Production disruptions at South Deep, Low reserve ounce mines ending before we currently forecast, Lower- than- expected gold price, Stronger- than- expected ZAR and AUD, Higher- than- expected cost inflation.

Our price objective of ZAR260/share (ADR US\$14.51) is set at c. 1.3x Price to NPV multiple (P/DCF using a WACC of \(5\%\) ). Through the cycle, HAR shares trade on average P/NPV of 1.3x. In an upward trending gold price environment, more operationally geared equities like HAR should outperform, in our view. Additionally, higher multiples tend to be paid during periods of rising precious metals prices. We have a positive view on gold, where our metals strategists think that gold can reach \(\) 4,000/oz\(in 2H25. However, HAR's gold hedges, declining production and growth execution risks weigh on upside during this high gold price environment.

The upside risks to our price objective are as follows: i) Additional production/value being realised from Mponeng and Moab Khotsong than we currently model. ii) Value realisation through sale of the Golpu project in Papua New Guinea (not our base case). iii) Higher- than- expected gold and copper prices. iv) Weaker- than- expected ZAR. v) Lower- than- expected cost inflation.

The downside risks to our price objective are i) higher- than- expected cost inflation in South Africa, predominantly from wages and electricity, ii) stronger- than- expected ZAR, iii) lower- than- expected gold prices, iv) labour unrest, v) production negatively impacted by a shortage of electricity in South Africa.

Our price objective of GBp350 is based on 0.9x 2026E NPV multiple, towards the middle of the 0.9- 1.5x historical valuation range. Our assumed WACC is \(5\%\) real with no terminal value. As the group continues to ramp up its new Mara Rosa project in Brazil, we think that market view of risk in the shares will decrease and we could / should see higher P/NPV multiples being paid.

Downside risks to our price objective are: risks to silver and gold prices, operational risk, political risk in South America, risks to company guidance on mine life and operational risk on Inmaculada.

Upside risks to our price objective other than commodity price are resolution of dispute with government which allows mines to produce normally, better than nameplate throughput at Inmaculada, higher- than- expected grades at legacy mines, and positive exploration results.

FUNDAMENTAL EQUITY OPINION KEY: Opinions include a Volatility Risk Rating, an Investment Rating and an Income Rating. VOLATILITY RISK RATINGS, indicators of potential price fluctuation, are: A - Low, B - Medium and C - High. INVESTMENT RATINGS reflect the analyst's assessment of both a stock's absolute total return potential as well as its attractiveness for investment relative to other stocks within its Coverage Cluster (defined below). Our investment ratings are: 1 - Buy stocks are expected to have a total return of at least \(10\%\) and are the most attractive stocks in the coverage cluster; 2 - Neutral stocks are expected to remain flat or increase in value and are less attractive than Buy rated stocks and 3 - Underperform stocks are the least attractive stocks in a coverage cluster. An investment rating of 6 (No Rating) indicates that a stock is no longer trading on the basis of fundamentals. Analysts assign investment ratings considering, among other things, the 0- 12 month total return expectation for a stock and the firm's guidelines for ratings dispersions (shown in the table below). The current price objective for a stock should be referenced to better understand the total return expectation at any given time. The price objective reflects the analyst's view of the potential price appreciation (depreciation).

INCOME RATINGS, indicators of potential cash dividends, are: 7 - same/higher (dividend considered to be secure), 8 - same/lower (dividend not considered to be secure) and 9 - pays no cash dividend. Coverage Cluster is comprised of stocks covered by a single analyst or two or more analysts sharing a common industry, sector, region or other classification(s). A stock's coverage cluster is included in the most recent BofA Global Research report referencing the stock.
